properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A total of 15 to 25 centimetres of snow is expected by Wednesday morning. The snow will be accompanied by strong winds which will reduce visibilities in blowing snow. Snow will change to rain overnight Tuesday night over the Chevery and Blanc-Sablon areas. A few hours of freezing rain are possible during the changeover from snow to rain. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T06:44:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T14:45:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3549697757.2019
Area: Forestville area, Les Escoumins area, Minganie, Natashquan, Chevery, Blanc-Sablon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall is expected. Total rainfall: 50 to 80 mm Locations: southwestern Newfoundland from Channel-Port aux Basques to Grey River. Time span: today until midday on Wednesday. Remarks: After a brief period of snow this morning precipitation has changed over to rain, except along the Burgeo highway where the snow will persist until early this afternoon. Rain at times heavy is forecast to continue through tonight before tapering off Wednesday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-13T06:25:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T14:26:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1400222022.2019
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall: 20 to 40 cm possible. Locations: Hopedale and vicinity, Postville - Makkovik. Time span: overnight tonight until Thursday morning. Remarks: The snow will be accompanied by strong north to northeasterly winds gusting up to 70 km/h on Wednesday giving reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Winds will further increase from the north to northwest Wednesday night, with gusts of 100 to 130 km/h possible, causing blizzard like conditions. As a result, this watch is likely to be upgraded to a warning in subsequent forecasts later today. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-13T06:57:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T14:58:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1657656944.2019
Area: Postville - Makkovik, Hopedale and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall is expected. Total rainfall: 35 to 55 mm. Locally higher amounts possible over higher terrain. Locations: Bay St. George up to the Bay of Islands Time span: this afternoon until early Wednesday afternoon. Remarks: After 5 to 10 cm snow today, precipitation is expected to transition to rain this afternoon. Warm temperatures and rain will combine to cause any existing snow pack to melt and may contribute to water pooling. Rain is forecast to continue through Tuesday night before transitioning to flurries Wednesday afternoon. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-13T06:22:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T14:23:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3828959408.2019
Area: Corner Brook and vicinity, Bay St. George
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls possible this afternoon. Flurries and local snow squalls are expected to begin this afternoon and continue into Wednesday. Local snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm per 12 hours are possible along with local blowing snow reducing visibilities to near zero. Local snow squalls are forecast to taper off when the winds shift to southwest on Wednesday. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T05:25:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T13:26:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3835717452.2019

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall amounts: 5 to 15 cm, highest amounts inland. Locations: Cartwright and south to L'Anse-au-Clair. Time span: This afternoon through to Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will develop this afternoon along the Labrador Straits and spread northward, reaching Cartwright this evening. The snow will then transition to rain from south to north overnight into Wednesday morning with a period of freezing rain likely over inland areas. Highest snowfall accumulations are expected inland and over higher terrain, particularly along the Trans-Labrador Highway, where temperatures will be slower to rise. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-13T06:56:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T14:57:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2230694883.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Storm moving into the region will bring significant rainfall today and continuing into Wednesday morning. Rain has begun across Nova Scotia and will continue tonight. Rainfall warnings have been issued for much of mainland Nova Scotia, except for Yarmouth, the Annapolis Valley region, and the Cobequid Peninsula. Rain will change to flurries over western Nova Scotia late tonight night as cold westerly winds move into the region and temperatures quickly fall below freezing. Driving conditions may become difficult overnight or Wednesday morning as the cold air and flurries push eastward across the province. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T06:59:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T15:00:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3257818206.2019

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Arctic air remains entrenched in the central interior as a frontal system crosses the BC Interior, delivering warm moist air aloft. Conditions are favourable for freezing rain mixed at times with ice pellets or snow. Freezing rain and ice pellets are forecast to change to rain showers by noon as warm air reaches the surface and brings temperatures above the freezing mark. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-12T19:59:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T12:25:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3564335748.2019
Area: Highway 97 - Clinton to 100 Mile House via Begbie Summit

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. Locations: Rigolet, Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River. Time span: Tonight, Wednesday, and Wednesday night. Remarks: The heaviest snowfall is expected overnight and Wednesday morning. Snow will be accompanied with north to northeasterly winds gusting to 50 or 60 km/h, resulting in blowing snow over exposed areas. Over eastern areas of the Trans-Labrador Highway in the Eagle River forecast region, a period of freezing rain is expected Wednesday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A Pacific frontal system is giving precipitation to the interior. Heavy snow over Shuswap and the South and North Thompson regions will continue this morning. The snow is expected to change to a few rain showers this afternoon as temperatures rise. About 5 cm of snow has already fallen and an additional 5 to 10 cm can be expected with the highest amounts over higher terrain for South Thompson and Shuswap. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Snow, ice pellets, and freezing rain to northwestern New Brunswick today. Snow will be heavy at times today, and is forecast to become mixed with ice pellets or freezing rain over portions of these regions except for Madawaska and Restigouche Counties, where precipitation is expected to remain as snow throughout the event. Precipitation is forecast to taper to scattered flurries this evening. Further snowfall amounts of near 25 cm are expected except only 5 cm for the Woodstock region. The travelling public are urged to prepare for potentially difficult driving conditions in snow and mixed precipitation. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T06:58:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T14:59:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3320786891.2019

properties.Summary:

Rain over the Islands is expected to become intermittent this afternoon, then redevelop tonight and continue into Wednesday morning. Total accumulations of 20 to 30 millimetres are currently forecast. Flurries are expected to begin by Wednesday afternoon, as brisk westerly winds usher in colder temperatures. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Rain is forecast to continue until Wednesday morning, with total forecast rainfall accumulations ranging from 40 to 60 millimetres over the region. Over higher terrain, snow will change to rain this morning as temperatures rise. Rain is expected to change to flurries on Wednesday morning as cold westerly winds move across the province. Flurries are likely to persist through the day on Wednesday and into Wednesday night, when conditions may become favourable for the development of snow squalls. The travelling public are urged to prepare for potentially difficult driving conditions in snow tonight and Tuesday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake Effect snow squalls continue today. Flurries and local snow squalls will continue to affect the area this morning and early this afternoon before moving out of the region in the late afternoon. Additional snowfall amounts of 20 to 30 cm are expected by late afternoon, with local blowing snow reducing visibilities to near zero at times. Travel is expected to be hazardous and squalls will have a significant impact on the morning commute. Local snow squalls are expected to taper off when the wind shifts to the northwest this evening. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Les Suêtes Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Strong winds expected from Margaree Harbour to Bay St. Lawrence today. Strong southeasterly winds with gusts up to 110 km/h will begin to diminish this afternoon as they shift to southerly. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Les Suêtes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls expected Wednesday. Southerly winds over the relatively warm waters of Lake Superior are expected to produce flurries and local snow squalls on Wednesday. The squalls could start as early as Wednesday morning and are expected to continue through Wednesday night. Local snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are possible on Wednesday, however areas closer to Lake Superior could see locally higher amounts of 15 to 25 cm. Additional amounts of 5 to 15 cm are possible Wednesday night into Thursday morning. Local blowing snow reducing visibilities will also be a concern. Local snow squalls are forecast to taper off when the winds shift to the northwest on Thursday. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Ice build-up due to freezing rain is expected or occurring. Light northerly outflow winds continue to bring modified arctic air through mainland valleys as a Pacific frontal system crosses the region. The combination of warm air from the approaching system overriding the cold outflow is producing freezing rain in valleys throughout the region. Freezing rain will persist until late this morning when temperatures finally rise above zero. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Ice build-up may cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds are expected or occurring. Maximum wind gusts: 100 to 120 km/h. Time span: today until early Wednesday morning. Remarks: Strong southeasterly winds with gusts up to 120 km/h are expected today. Winds will diminish slightly tonight, but gusts between 80 to 100 km/h are still expected. Winds are forecast to diminish early Wednesday morning when they shift to westerly. ### Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-13T06:22:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T14:23:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3919532738.2019
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain or rain will change to periods of rain near noon. The travelling public are urged to prepare for potentially difficult driving conditions in areas of freezing rain. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-12T20:04:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T14:56:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2358867507.2019
Area: Fredericton and Southern York County, Oromocto and Sunbury County, St. Stephen and Northern Charlotte County, Stanley - Doaktown - Blackville Area
properties.Author: Environment Canada
